content.description:
This is a short 5 bolt lead. It is great for new leaders or a warm-up.

Eds. This used to be a trad lead before the retrobolts.
content.protection: Draws.
content.location: This is climber's left of the toprope slab and 20 feet around the corner to the left.

content.description: This is the second left-most route, just right of the slab, [right]-angling crack, then up through roof (crux). 4 bolts and a few stoppers help lessen the run-out.
content.protection: Draws, medium stoppers, especially for below roof.
content.location:
This on the left side of

Bob's Crack

.

content.description: This is great route for beginners.  There is an easy start to some moves that may will make a 5.6 - 5.7 climber think.  This climb has large flakes and even some cracks.
content.protection: 3 bolts at the top as anchors.
content.location: This is the leftmost climb on Bob's Rock.

content.description: This has hard climbing on thin edges on the face left of Wire Man Crack (right-leaning crack, 11a) 5 bolts 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: Draws, 2 bolt anchor at top.
content.location: It is left of right-leaning thin crack.

content.description:
This is a short, 5 bolt sport route on the south side of Bob's 5 feet to left of

Rio de Jean Perro

. You can link up into

Rio...

.
content.protection: Quickdraws.

content.description: This has face and crack climbing up a steep wall and a bulge.  Ya gotta figure out if you want to try to pull the bulge on the left or right at the 3rd bolt.
content.protection: 6 bolts, a few hand-sized cams for comfort, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: At Bob's Rock, hike around the left side and up to the obvious, next little tower.  This is the bolted line up the right side of the face.

content.description:
This is a nice, little route up the arete. You can thank Sarah DeNicholas for this one. The crux is between bolt 4 and bolt 6.

Bobby Lewis set the route.
content.protection: Quickdraws. There are rap rings at the top for the anchor.
content.location: This is on the leftmost face of Bob's near the easier climbs. It is the rightmost climb on this face. If you want to set a TR, it is easy to get around to the top from the back side.

content.description:
This route is 20 feet left & downhill of

Depends

and just to the right of the newly bolted 11.a on the south side of Bob's. It is a 10 bolt sport route on big jugs up steep terrain.
content.protection: 10 draws.

content.description: Begin below the broken, right-facing corner.  Climb left past 2 ring bolts to the right-angling crack system.  Continue up and left past 3 more bolts to the anchor.
content.protection: A medium-sized (#1 or #2 Camalot) cam works between the 2nd and 3rd bolt.
content.location: Start on the right side of Bob's Rock, traverse left, and go up onto the overhung shield of Bob's Rock.

content.description: This is on the right side of Bob's Rock.  It has a couple tricky moves.  The name fits it perfectly.
content.protection: Place a piece or two of gear to start, then clip 5 bolts on the face.
content.location: This is on the south side of Bob's Rock.  It is #12 in the picture.

content.description:
Do the same start as

Chilcat

, and climb up the short, moderate crack. Continue straight up, instead of going up the ramp to the right, to

Chilcat’s

hard sections. Eventually, angle left and up, joining

Hot Foot and High Step

below its last bolt.

This is a fun moderate for the Ark Valley climber.
content.protection: A standard rack, 1 bolt, and bolted anchors.
content.location:
Climb the same start as

Chilcat

.

content.description:
Climb

Bob's Crack

for 25 feet, exit left into a left-facing corner and climb over the roof to a left-angling seam. Follow the seam to the top with a crux about 2/3 of the way up.
content.protection: The first ascent was climbed using pre placed Ball Nutz and a fixed copperhead. A few small to medium cams are useful before the roof. Two bolt anchor and chains.

content.description: In the center of Bob's Rock, there is an obvious lieback flake to start (crux) that continues to an angling crack to a dihedral.
content.protection: 2 bolts atop the dihedral, bring a medium sized rack, nothing bigger than 3 inches.
content.location: This goes up the middle of the face.

content.description: Climb to the ledge then follow 3 bolts next to seam.  Finish up and left, pull a small roof (easier), then go up into the dihedral to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: Quickdraws and maybe a few cams small to medium-sized.
content.location: This is on the middle right side of the rock.

content.description: Climb a slab to a stance where you can clip the first bolt. Continue on thin 5.11 moves past the first bolt. It is 5.10 or easier climbing past the next two bolts to the base of the overhang. Bust out the crux overhang, and clip the anchor on the ledge.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Start on the blunt arete between the south and west face (the first bolt is 15' up).

content.description:
This is a new route on the south side between the main wall and the Tool Wall.  Watch out for lots of loose rock and guano. The route needs a lot of cleaning!

The leader and belayer are highly advised to wear a helmet. Also, when rapping off, be aware that there is a bit of a swing when lowering (around the 2nd bolt), and you need to watch out for the tree.
content.protection: 10 bolts to 2- ½" shuts.

content.description: The route begins on 25 feet of 5.5 up to a ramp. If you place gear in this section, use a long runner to avoid rope drag up above. After moving right up the ramp 10 feet, continue up bulges and cracks another 25 feet. This middle section is 5.9ish. After gaining the ledge, shake out, and prepare for the crux above.  The upper section is 30 feet of steep 5.10.  The first ten feet is bolt protected due to an expanding flake. The top anchors have chains to reduce rope drag.
content.protection: Trad gear from 0.3-2" (a single rack should be plenty), 2 bolts, and bolt anchors with chains.
content.location:
Chilcat is left of

Spotty Lives

and right of

Hot Foot & High Step

.

content.description:
Use the same start as "

Hot Foot & High Step

." The crux comes between the third and fourth bolt.
content.protection: 6 bolts and a possible #2 to get one to the first bolt
content.location: This is on the right side of Bob's Rock.

content.description: This is the obvious and excellent crack on the right side of Bob's Rock. The pro for the first ~15' is poor/nil because of the flaring cracks. After the small ledge, the crack is a perfect vertical to overhanging hand crack. The rock takes good pro and the fall is safe. Definitely a good place to push yourself if it is at your limit.
content.protection: A set of nuts, hexes. Cams from tips to fist, possibly doubles in hand sizes. A 50m rope will get you down.

climbs.name: Bob 'n Betty Buttress
climbs.fa: Eric Simons, Mark Zander, Craig Nielson, September 15, 2019

content.description: This is a fun, well-protected mixed route up a series of short corners to chain anchors. It is a good addition to the easy/moderate routes on Bob's left side.
content.protection: 3 bolts and cams to 3" to chain anchors.
content.location:
On the crag 30 yards east of the toprope slab is an obvious buttress just to the right of

Special Bob

.

content.description:
Climb the crack just around the corner from

Bob's Crack

on the right side of Bob's Rock.
content.protection: Small pro up to #1/#2.
